review_title: Good to start your career, but don't stay there
pros:
- Money always on time
- Relaxed work culture
- Lots of people to help you expand your network and knowledge
cons:
- Does not pay well in comparison to other companies
- Does not offer any meaningful raises. Be careful to negotiate your salary very well during the interview, because probably that is all you will be taking as long as you stay here
- Older engineers could very well be making more money than you, even if you are the better engineer and offer more to the team. The company operates very much based on how many years you are working here.
- Nepotism

Because of all the above, great engineers do not stay long. And when they leave, they take the know-how with them. Attrition runs rampant and management knows this, but doesn't care. Everyone is expendable to them.

pros: employee friendly, work life balance

review_title: Good benefits, but not a very progressive dev environment
pros:
- Good benefits
- Great vacation policy compared to other companies
- Great work/life balance
cons:
Although most are awesome, there are a few senior software developers who are very difficult to work with (and these developers tend to make most of the important design decisions). 

It's openly known within the organization who the difficult people are, and other senior developers jokingly say things like "Oh, that's just X's personality, they treat everyone like that, you'll get used to it.".

It's very difficult to have an impact as a newer developer. Some of the devs have been there for 20+ years, so expect to be shut-down (or ignored) if you propose any modifications or improvements to their code/product.

cons: No competence development plan, no trainings, huge lack of leadership, low and middle managers just care about their upper managers and are totally negligent to what is going on below them. Result, everyday talented people are leaving Nokia and instead of creating a plan to motivate and take the best from collaborators, Global HR created a new policy to “retain” talents, which is, if you leave the company before 31st March the bonus which is related to the performance on previous year won”t be paid.

pros:
I'm a former employee and my experience was generally good. The work was challenging. Work colleagues were very supportive.

The new CEO is a very positive driver for change and I hope Nokia will!
cons:
Top-level management just wants to grind you into the ground. Lack of progression, lack of time to train and develop. They will bleed you to death and then kick you out.

Timelines on major projects are ridiculously short leading to missed planning and bad handovers to delivery teams. The product houses are under-resourced and unable to provide any decent help, cross-team projects can become heated. 

HR thinks they know the law but have blatantly broken UK law on multiple occasions.

pros:
Good employer in lower job grades
Some line managers can be called human
Used to be a lot of travelling
cons:
Huge hidden discrimination in salaries
Overtime hours 'explained' - not paid for
Some organizational units totally perversed and bully their employees
Constant 'management with fear' culture
'Travel request' is a curse word nowadays
Tweaked games in HR when it comes to employee policies - they always have some 'explanation' to a suspected mistreatment or grievance
Investments to employees ZERO - no team-building events, no salary increases (budgets nearly zero)
They make employees race against others in terms of performance - back at the years they even made a global rule that a 5% share of employees had to be dropped below the 'performance line' regardless how well all the team members performed
All in all - people management, processes and policies suck the BIG Time!

* There is an emphasis on continuous development so there is to some degree a possibility to take different kinds of courses and training (for example lean six sigma training).

cons:

* It is stressful (for a few months almost every year) to have regular yearly labor negotiations after which many employees are let go. review_title: Nokia pays you just enough to be in the company and keep working
pros:
1. you will learn a lot if you are put into a good team. 
2. usually work culture is pretty good in the R&D team.
3. colleagues are mostly helpful.
4. don't have to keep slogging.
cons:
1. company pays you just enough so that you usually will not do all the tiring work of finding a new job.
2. when you are in development in a considerably big team you will usually not get important feature to develop on your application. It's quite hard to be like in the forefront of a feature development if you are a junior. 
3. you have to be very lucky to be in a team where not too many senior tech leads/architects are there so that you actually get exposure to develop and design a feature from the forefront and someone is just mentoring you. 
4. the problem in the R&D teams are technical architects, they don't move and go to a new team so that the juniors can get the chance of showing their capabilities. As i said one has to be very lucky to get better opportunities in the team

job_title: Network Support Engineer in Bristol, England
pros:
- Get to work on huge/cutting edge networks
- Good work/life balance
- Nice offices
- Fair on call pay scheme
- Good IT/hardware/labs
- Generally decent (if unfriendly) people
- Good place to get an entry level job and start your career.
- Generally the work load is not excessive, as they employ so many people (could be seen as a con - this is due to middle management empire building)
cons:
If you work at Nokia, there are 0 prospects for career progression. They actively discourage people switching roles. You CANNOT get a pay rise for switching roles. If you are in a team earning 30K a year, and join a team where a new hire would get 40K, you will stay on 30K. This is the stupidest policy I have ever heard of at a company, and is why most people only work here a couple of years, or forever. There is a weird culture of people joining the company at an entry level, and keeping that job until retirement. If you work there for decades they will eventually give you a pay grade bump and you'll get more money, but this is the only way to increase your salary. This is the reason why I left, and is a shame as it was a good place to work.
You can only get a significant pay rise if you stay there for 10+ years.

And having said all that, the pay is WAY below average. I changed jobs, and got almost double the salary.

Major con is extremely unfriendly office culture. To the point where people will not even acknowledge you if you say hello to them in the kitchen. Teams do not mix at all.

Ridiculous internal processes (by the time you get approval to buy something, the quote you got has expired) but probably no worse than other large corporations.

Incredibly disorganized, severe lack of respect in the company culture, very limited growth opportunities and hardly any pay increase opportunities. HR does not keep reports confidential, and hiring recruiters make promises for future opportunities that haven't existed since the 2000s & would be impossible to obtain. Also no respect for work life balance - management holds the expectation that you will give your life over for your job, especially if you are young. Find a company that will value you instead.

review_title: Work for Nokia if you really need a job until something else is available
pros: Pretty good benefits, vacation days, flexible work schedule, Bonuses are paid out when business unit and company kit their Key performance indexes. Have not be at the 100% payout level since Alcatel-Lucent was acquired by Nokia.
cons: Constant layoffs and pressure to reduce staff - move jobs to lower cost countries, Management has struggled for many years and implement headcount reductions without regard for work and have a plug and play mentality where experience and knowledge is not as important as headcount. Experienced employees are laid off when there is still work to be done - other employees are moved in to do the same work which kills what little morale is left. Most years there are no raises in the US or they are very minimal. A new round of layoffs of 10,000 employees was announced at the beginning of 2021. If you can find another employee go there. pros: Good corporate culture, strong learning environment

pros:
Good salary and performance driven initiative

Around three weeks of paid location

No micromanagement
cons:
Slow processes

Working with India team on their time zone

Poor communication within the team

The manager has not done 1:1 in 6
months

No-one turned on their webcam in any meetings even I worked there for years

A great deal of difference in work culture from what it appears to be on Linkedin for teams in Europe and teams in Ottawa.

The company￼ hasn't given a single dollar for clearing certifications

Haven’t given a penny for work from home setup

Every 2 years, the company does a lot of changes on the upper management restructuring. You will receive long emails about what they are planning to do and what they are doing. But literally, at your level, nothing will change. So in the end, the company will be doing a lot of restructuring just because new leaders came and they want to do things their way￼. Overall, so do you think creates a lot of uncertainty with employees and lack of trust in company policy￼

Poor intra-team communications

Almost 0 events for team building. Just one event was organized where we met in the park, that's it!

On 16th March 2021, Nokia announced that it will lay off 10k employees within 1-2 years because of that the motivation was impacted

Gave 0% increment at end of the year for no good reason￼

Gave no perks except the standard insurance plan.

Being in development, when asked for Mac I was told that Windows is the only option that you can have, awesome 🙌

Most teams rely on VLab (an IaaS) to deploy/perform/test their work, I was not assigned a lab for more than a year. Everybody in the management kept saying that we are short of resources. How can you deploy 10 versions of 50 GB software on a single Lenovo machine and be productive?

The NCS team has good documentation, most of the others I have seen rely on confluence pages most of which are outdated or hard to find.

No of rounds to get the job was lesser, so it will be better if they hire quality people rather than just hiring in a single meeting.

review_title: A good company with very bad management
pros:
- It is not a strict environment in several ways. The are some managers that support their team but this is a minority.
- Working from home is ok without been pushed to go to office.
cons:
- Management (low & high level) does not support at all people's efforts in any way. Financially and in all other ways. 
- Upper management most of the times takes advantage of employees who are involved in side projects - tasks not related to the business but are related to the local site. An illusion of then extra mile and "best effort" work that leads to exploitation. No reward of any kind.
- The majority of the line managers are not supposed to deal with people and carriers. It is the first time I saw totally incapable managers trying to handle excellent engineers... As a result, the Nokia Athens lost many excellent engineers and got stuck with poor performers and average performance employees. If you try to speak up & raise possible issues, most probably you will get into a "black list"
- 50% of the working environment is not suitable for employees. One of the 2 buildings is totally not meant to host people.
- The company has great tolerance to political parties and all kind of surreal political actions. You can do whatever you want (emails, working station visits, etc) and noone will stop you.
